thread.title: Jalen Powe, surging Warren Blue Devils show poise under pressure Lake County News-Sun
thread.title_full: Jalen Powe, surging Warren Blue Devils show poise under pressure - Lake County News-Sun

author: David Perry
title: Jalen Powe, surging Warren Blue Devils show poise under pressure Lake County News-Sun
text:
Say this for the football players for the Warren Blue Devils: They do not panic.
They did not panic when they opened the season by failing to score in seven consecutive quarters.
They did not panic when that scoring drought led to a pair of season-opening losses that put a playoff berth in early season jeopardy.
And last Friday night, they did not panic when Stevenson drove 78 yards in 11 plays to take a 27-23 lead with 1:22 to go in a game the Devils needed to win to remove themselves from that playoff jeopardy and be in position to win the North Suburban Lake title.
The Devils' response to that Stevenson drive that ate up 4:41 of precious time?
A game-winning touchdown 12 seconds later on a 93-yard kickoff return by Jalen Powe, followed by game-clinching interceptions by Zavion Armour and Keylan Stocker on Stevenson's final two possessions as Warren stunned the defending Class 8A state champions 30-27 and drove a huge homecoming crowd into delirium.
There's a word for plays like that and, just like "panic," it starts with the letter "P."
Poise.
"I saw the biggest hole I saw all night," Powe said. "I just burst threw it. It was wide open, and I had great blocking."
Actually, Warren's kick return team executed well all night, as Powe seemed close to a big return on earlier kickoffs, only to be denied by Stevenson.
But when the Blue Devils (4-2, 4-0) needed it, Powe & Co. came through. And then it was up to the Warren defense to protect the slim lead.
Stevenson quarterback Jack Sorenson, a starting wideout on the 2014 championship team, moved the Patriots to the Warren 43-yard line. Then, quicker than the time it took Powe to return the kickoff to the end zone, Stevenson's threat ended as Armour got his hands on a pass near the Warren 20.
Stevenson (3-3, 1-2) used its timeouts to get one final shot at the win, and Stocker ended that with his pick on the final play.
"These kids have come ready to play. They rally and overcome," Warren coach Bryan McNulty said. "We told them there would be adversity in this game. We knew this game would be a see-saw, but we emphasized, 'Stay in the fight.' and we did."
Stevenson led 7-0 after a quarter on Sorenson's 1-yard run. Warren went up 10-7 on a 33-yard touchdown pass from Kyle Debevec to Nicholas Marcinkus, and a 21-yard field goal by Brandon Hergenreder.
Stevenson then went up 14-10 at the half on Henry Marchese's 4-yard TD pass from Sorenson with 35 seconds on the clock.
A TD run by Darrius Crump (26 carries, 155 yards) gave Warren a 17-14 lead, but Tyler Vincent (13 carries, 171 yards) raced 80 yards from scrimmage to flip the game back in Stevenson's favor at 21-17.
Crump's second TD run made it 23-21 with 6:09 left in the game, and Vincent's 5-yard TD run put Stevenson up 27-23 and set the stage for Powe.
Debevec finished 12-for-20 passing for 160 yards. Sorenson was 15-for-26 for 180 yards, with Marchese catching 10 of the throws.
Next Friday night, Warren plays at Libertyville (6-0, 4-0), the NSC Lake title will be on the line.
Warren may win, or it may not. But Libertyville definitely cannot count on the Blue Devils panicking because the big-game lights are too bright.
"We talked about working hard, focusing and doing our assignments all week," Crump said. "In the second half, it showed we wanted it more. They gave us a fight, but we pulled it out.
"We play with heart, and we'll show Libertyville that next week."
David Perry is a freelance writer for the News-Sun.
